verses.text: Benjamin fathered Bela his firstborn, Ashbel the second, Aharah the third,
verses.comment: These are the sons of Benjamin, introducing the genealogy that forms part of the line of Saul, Israel’s first king. Genealogies served to preserve the priestly and kingly lines, foreshadowing the need for legitimate succession for the coming Messiah.

verses.text: Nohah the fourth, and Rapha the fifth.
verses.comment: Continuing the sons of Benjamin. The meticulous record-keeping highlights God’s fidelity to His promises, preserving Israel for His chosen work.

verses.text: Bela’s sons were Addar, Gera, Abihud,
verses.comment: These names reflect significant ancestors within Benjamin’s descendants. Gera, notably, is the ancestor of Ehud, raised up by God as a deliverer (Judg 3:15).

verses.text: Abishua, Naaman, Ahoah,
verses.comment: The line of Bela outlines individual family heads who will build the tribe’s future—setting the stage for the history to follow.

verses.text: Gera, Shephuphan, and Huram.
verses.comment: Repetition of Gera here may indicate another Gera or simply reflect alternate spellings—a sign of careful preservation of tradition, reflecting the importance of memory and history in the faith community.

verses.text: These are the sons of Ehud—they were the heads of fathers’ houses of the inhabitants of Geba, and they were carried into exile to Manahath:
verses.comment: Exile here marks divine judgment as well as God’s ongoing demand for faithfulness. Ehud is remembered for his deliverance of Israel—a subtle typology pointing to the ultimate deliverer, Christ.

verses.text: Naaman, Ahijah, and Gera, who led them into exile; he fathered Uzza and Ahihud.
verses.comment: Mention of exile again points to the consequences of unfaithfulness but also to God’s discipline, meant to restore and purify His people.

verses.text: Shaharaim fathered sons in the country of Moab after he had sent away Hushim and Baara his wives.
verses.comment: The intermarriage with Moabites is noted, paralleling other links with Ruth, the Moabite ancestor of David. It hints at God’s mysterious plan to draw nations to Himself.

verses.text: By his wife Hodesh, he fathered Jobab, Zibia, Mesha, Malcam,
verses.comment: These lines show the complex family history, including multiple wives and cross-cultural unions, all within the unfolding of salvation history.

verses.text: Jeuz, Sachia, and Mirmah. These were his sons, heads of fathers’ houses.
verses.comment: Naming the heads of houses emphasizes leadership and spiritual fatherhood as central in God’s covenant family.

verses.text: He also fathered sons by Hushim: Abitub and Elpaal.
verses.comment: Parallel family lines show the spread of Benjaminite tribes, anticipating later tensions and reunions in Israel’s story.

verses.text: The sons of Elpaal: Eber, Misham, Shemed (who built Ono and Lod, with their villages),
verses.comment: Ono and Lod will later become return communities after the exile. These builders show the ongoing mission to restore and dwell the Promised Land, prefiguring the restoration of the faithful remnant.

verses.text: And Beriah and Shema (they were heads of fathers’ houses of the inhabitants of Aijalon; they drove out the inhabitants of Gath),
verses.comment: Conquest and settlement are keys to Israel’s story, and these drive out pagan inhabitants—a type of spiritual warfare and preparation for holiness.

verses.text: Ahio, Shashak, and Jeremoth.
verses.comment: These lists maintain the continuity of tribal identity and the idea of succession through legitimate lines—an underlying theme in the biblical vision of the church’s unity and apostolicity.

verses.text: The sons of Beriah: Zebadiah, Arad, Eder,
verses.comment: The consistent listing is a mark of historical faithfulness and deep respect for God’s order.

verses.text: Michael, Ishpah, and Joha.
verses.comment: Michael is a frequent name in Israel. Later Jewish tradition connects the Archangel Michael with spiritual warfare and divine protection.

verses.text: The sons of Elpaal: Zebadiah, Meshullam, Hizki, Heber,
verses.comment: Listing the sons indicates the continuing multiplication of God’s chosen people, whom He disciplines and guides throughout history.

verses.text: Ishmerai, Izliah, and Jobab.
verses.comment: Jobab—and others—demonstrate God’s faithfulness to His covenant through generation after generation.

verses.text: The sons of Shimei: Jakim, Zichri, Zabdi,
verses.comment: Even obscure lines serve to express the breadth of God’s people—each member, no matter how hidden, is remembered by God.

verses.text: Eliënai, Zillethai, and Eliel,
verses.comment: These names carry echoes of praise and devotion (e.g., ‘God is my God’), subtly demonstrating the intended worshipful posture of Israel.

verses.text: Adaiah, Beraiah, and Shimrath.
verses.comment: The cumulative history here creates a vision of shared faith and remembrance—an essential model for God’s people in every age.

verses.text: The sons of Shashak: Ishpan, Eber, Eliel,
verses.comment: Another branch of the family lines, testifying to God’s providential care in all generations.

verses.text: Abdon, Zichri, and Hanan,
verses.comment: Each name affirms a unique part in God’s plan—no individual is too obscure for God’s purpose.

verses.text: Hananiah, Elam, Anthothijah,
verses.comment: Anthothijah perhaps reflects a connection to Anathoth, later a priestly town (see Jer. 1:1)—connecting genealogies to spiritual leadership.

verses.text: Iphdeiah, and Penuel.
verses.comment: Penuel (related to ‘face of God’) alludes to places of encounter with God, pointing to the importance of direct yet mediated relationship with the divine.

verses.text: The sons of Jeroham: Shamsherai, Shehariah, Athaliah,
verses.comment: Athaliah is the name of a notorious queen in Judah. These shared names across Israel’s history reinforce God’s consistent and sovereign guidance.

verses.text: Jaareshiah, Elijah, and Zichri.
verses.comment: Elijah is a significant prophetic name in Israel’s story, and its recurrence points to the importance of the prophetic in the life of God’s people.

verses.text: These were heads of fathers’ houses, according to their generations, chief men. These lived in Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Jerusalem’s settlers play a special spiritual role. Living in the holy city points to participation in the place of God’s worship and presence, looking forward to the eternal city (Rev 21:2).

verses.text: Jeiel the father of Gibeon lived in Gibeon, and the name of his wife was Maacah.
verses.comment: Genealogies tie the leaders of Gibeon directly to Benjamin’s line. Place and ancestry are both tied to the unfolding story of God’s kingdom.

verses.text: His firstborn son was Abdon, then Zur, Kish, Baal, Nadab,
verses.comment: Kish here is notable: the father of Saul, Israel’s first king. Saul’s genealogy points to a God-ordained monarchy.

verses.text: Gedor, Ahio, Zecher, and Mikloth.
verses.comment: Mikloth will be mentioned again in genealogies detailing royal and priestly service—important roles handed down through generations.

verses.text: Mikloth fathered Shimeah. Now these also lived opposite their relatives in Jerusalem, with their brothers.
verses.comment: Living ‘opposite’ their kin suggests close communal life and mutual accountability, representing the unity of God’s household.

verses.text: Ner fathered Kish, Kish fathered Saul, Saul fathered Jonathan, Malchishua, Abinadab, and Eshbaal.
verses.comment: Saul’s lineage is crucial; Jonathan plays a significant covenant role with David. The faithfulness of Jonathan and his sacrifice foreshadow Jesus’ faithful laying down of life for his friends (John 15:13).

verses.text: The son of Jonathan was Merib-baal; and Merib-baal fathered Micah.
verses.comment: 'Merib-baal' is also called 'Mephibosheth.' The shift in names reflects both reverence for God and a reluctance to speak the name 'Baal,' showing Israel’s call to purity.

verses.text: The sons of Micah were Pithon, Melech, Tarea, and Ahaz.
verses.comment: The descendants of Jonathan continue as a testimony to God’s mercy and the endurance of faithful lines, despite challenges.

verses.text: Ahaz fathered Jehoaddah, and Jehoaddah fathered Alemeth, Azmaveth, and Zimri; Zimri fathered Moza;
verses.comment: Marking out the generations shows the rhythmic unfolding of God’s providence and the organic growth of the people set aside for God’s glory.

verses.text: Moza fathered Binea; Raphah was his son, Eleasah his son, Azel his son.
verses.comment: Continuity through these generations indicates the need for stability in leadership and faithfulness to God’s promises.

verses.text: Azel had six sons, and these are their names: Azrikam, Bocheru, Ishmael, Sheariah, Obadiah, and Hanan. All these were sons of Azel.
verses.comment: Obadiah is the name of a prophet; the repetition of key names throughout Scripture links various events and persons in God’s plan. Multiplicity of sons demonstrates God’s blessing.

verses.text: The sons of Eshek his brother: Ulam his firstborn, Jeush the second, and Eliphelet the third.
verses.comment: This list rounds off the third branch; these names will echo later in Scripture as well.

verses.text: The sons of Ulam were mighty warriors, archers, having many sons and grandsons, one hundred and fifty in all. All these were Benjaminites.
verses.comment: Benjamin was known for its warriors and archers. This ends the genealogy, connecting strength, legacy, and spiritual faithfulness—concepts fulfilled in the New Covenant people as spiritual warriors and heirs of God.
